webTitle: Tesco pays out to rid itself of US chain Fresh & Easy

fields.standfirst: US billionaire Ron Burkle's Yucaipa investment vehicle agrees to take on 150 stores and 4,000 staff
fields.body:
Tesco has finally negotiated an exit from its failed expansion into the US by lending US billionaire Ron Burkle £80m to take away its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain.

After more than nine months searching for a buyer, Burkle's Yucaipa investment vehicle has agreed to take on 150 Fresh & Easy stores as well as 4,000 staff and a vast distribution centre and production facility east of Los Angeles.

The deal will cost Tesco £150m in total, including the loan, payoffs for about 400 permanent staff and the closure of about 50 stores not included in the deal – taking the total cost of the humiliating episode to nearly £2bn. The future for a further 600 staff is unclear, with some expats likely to return to Tesco in the UK while others are part-time staff and will be let go.

Philip Clarke, the UK supermarket's chief executive, said: "The decision we are announcing today represents the best outcome for Tesco shareholders and Fresh & Easy's stakeholders. It offers us an orderly and efficient exit from the US market, while protecting the jobs of more than 4,000 colleagues."

Tesco said that the deal would mean there was no ongoing financial exposure in the US. However, under the agreement, which is expected to be finalised by the end of the year, Tesco will hold warrants that entitle it to a 32.5% stake in the holding company that will run Fresh & Easy, should certain performance criteria be met. They could be exchanged for a cash sum in the future.

Ron Burkle, managing partner of Yucaipa, who founded the Ralphs and Food4Less supermarket chains in the US, indicated that he planned to continue to run Fresh & Easy as a standalone chain.

He said: "Fresh & Easy is a tremendous foundation. Tesco should be applauded for giving their customers an affordable, healthy, convenient shopping experience. Its dedicated employees and great base of customers give us a solid starting point to complete Tesco's vision with some changes that we think will make it even more relevant to today's consumer."

He said Yucaipa planned to build the chain into a "next-generation convenience retail experience". However, there has been speculation that Burkle wants to use the Fresh & Easy stores to relaunch his Wild Oats brand, which he sold to rival Whole Foods Market in 2007.

The deal is good news for Tesco after weeks of speculation that it would be unable to find a buyer for its US business. The trip over the Atlantic, begun in 2007 with ambitious plans for thousands of stores, has proved very costly for Tesco with trading losses and investment reaching some £1.8bn.

The failure has not only meant problems for Tesco but tarnished the reputation of former chief executive Sir Terry Leahy, who was previously held up as a shining example of British retail success.

It also reflected badly on Tim Mason, the Tesco marketing supremo who was relocated to the US to run Fresh & Easy and build it into a chain the same size as Tesco UK. He was made redundant earlier this year with more than £2m.

It was not clear on Tuesday night if Tesco would have to make further write downs after completing the deal.

Selling off the US business is good news for Clarke, who has been attempting to get rid of poorly performing overseas assets in order to concentrate on Tesco's problems at home.

In April, the supermarket reported its first fall in annual profits for 20 years as its chains both abroad and at home suffered during a global downturn.

The ongoing losses in the US were blamed for a squeeze on expenditure in the UK which meant that stores began to look tired and customer service suffered. Tesco has also suffered from a series of PR disasters including revelations that some of its burgers contained horse meat.

Tesco recently revealed it was in negotiations to put its Chinese business into a new joint venture with the state-owned Chain Resources Enterprise. The deal, which would cost Tesco an estimated £1.5bn, would merge its 131 stores into CRE's Vanguard chain, which has nearly 3,000 outlets.

webTitle: Tesco US Fresh & Easy debacle gets worse

fields.standfirst: The supermarket has been forced to give away its failed chain to the billionaire Ron Burkle with a big loan attached
fields.body:
Tesco's miserable investment in its US Fresh & Easy chain is ending in miserable fashion: the "buyer" is Ron Burkle, but the billionaire will not have to dip into his considerable fortune to complete the deal because Tesco is giving away the business with an £80m ($125m) loan. Tesco could not even persuade Burkle to take all 200 stores. He has picked 150; Tesco will bear the cost of closing the others.

The supermarket giant has wasted almost £2bn on Fresh & Easy, counting investment and trading losses, since 2007. The harder-to-quantify expense is the loss of competitiveness in the core UK business, which the chief executive, Philip Clarke, has been trying to correct since the profits warning in January last year. The two are connected, as the former chairman Lord MacLaurin pointed out in June in his damning analysis of the "sad" legacy left by his successor, Sir Terry Leahy. "It's unforgivable that he took money out of the UK business and allowed it to flounder when our rivals were catching up and expanding," said MacLaurin. Quite.

webTitle: Gulf Keystone wins court battle over Kurdistan oilfields

fields.standfirst: Judge in London dismisses claim made by Excalibur Ventures
fields.body:
Gulf Keystone Petroleum has won a long-standing court case over the ownership of potentially lucrative oilfields in Kurdistan, paving the way for a possible sale of the exploration group.

Excalibur Ventures, formed by former US special forces solider Rex Wempen, began legal action against Gulf Keystone in 2010, claiming it had helped introduce the company to the region and was entitled to up to 30% of the assets.

In a packed London courtroom, judge Christopher Clarke dismissed the claim. He said a collaboration agreement between Gulf Keystone, Wempen and his brother Eric in 2006 did not "create, give rise to, or recognise any entitlement of Excalibur to an indirect interest in [the assets]."

The judge adjourned the hearing to a later date to discuss costs and any possible appeal. But analysts at Mirabaud said the victory was decisive and an appeal was unlikely to go ahead.

Gulf Keystone's chief executive Todd Kozel said: "We are very pleased to have achieved the best possible outcome from the point of view of the company and our shareholders." Many of the company's army of private investors were in attendance and applauded Kozel after the judgement was announced.

The main asset involved is the Shaikan field, which is estimated to hold around 12bn barrels of oil, making it one of the largest oil discoveries in recent years.

Gulf Keystone's shares were briefly suspended ahead of the ruling, but ended nearly 17% higher at 219.25p, valuing the company at more than £1.9bn.

It is one of the biggest companies on Aim and has ambitions to move to a full listing. But many analysts believe that with the court case out of the way, it could attract the attention of major oil companies such as Exxon Mobil, Chevron and Gazprom who have begin to take an interest in Kurdistan, a semi-autonomous region in northern Iraq.

Will Forbes, analyst at Edison Investment Research, said: "After winning the case against Excalibur claim, Gulf Keystone investors can at last concentrate on other key catalysts for the stock including a move to a full FTSE listing - we expect before the end of this year – and the first meaningful production from Shaikan from the 20,000 barrels per day early production facilities, due to start up imminently."

But Dragan Trajkov and Jamal Orazbayeva at Westhouse said: "The market's perception is that the conclusion of the case removes an obstacle towards the sale of Gulf Keystone. However, we believe that the main obstacle for a potential sale is political uncertainty in Kurdistan rather than the litigation case. Thus, we think this may be a good exit opportunity for investors."

webTitle: Marks & Spencer revamp to give shops department-store feel

fields.standfirst: Chief executive says new look will improve 'shopability' at M&S as John Lewis looks likely to draw level in sales
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is aiming to win back shoppers by making its stores look and feel more like a department store. The change comes as its rival John Lewis looks set to draw level with M&S sales this year.

In the 80 largest stores, M&S is dividing its main Collection range of womenswear into defined areas for single products including coats, dresses, denim and knitwear. There will also be casual, smart and tailoring departments. Each area, which in the 15 top stores will be divided into near-separate rooms, will include appropriate accessories such as belts, footwear and scarves as well as mannequins that help to suggest outfits.

The chief executive, Marc Bolland, who is under pressure to improve sales of women's clothing at the high street stalwart, said revamped fashions going into stores were "directionally right" and "on track" according to customers, staff and the press. He said: "What we see now is product coming out much better because it has got the environment it deserves."

The Dutchman, who joined M&S more than three years ago from the supermarket chain Morrisons, has overseen a revival in trading in the retailer's food department. But shareholders have suggested Bolland's job could be on the line if clothing sales do not show signs of improvement this season after two years of decline.

Bolland insisted: "Addressing womenswear is extremely important but autumn/winter is a first step. It is not make or break."

He said the new-look stores improved the "shopability". He added: "We are not turning into department stores, we are just departmentalising the shopping journey a bit more."

M&S's new stores were revealed as John Lewis is expected to reveal a 6% rise in half-year profits on Thursday. The department store group is on track to exceed its rival's UK sales for the first time.

Perhaps with the famous service of John Lewis in mind, the new look for M&S is accompanied by "Fashion Camp" retraining for all 10,000 staff working in womenswear to improve their knowledge about the chain's clothing. Staff are being urged to put aside other tasks to step on to tills if queues build up and to offer advice to shoppers.

In three large stores in the London area, including the Pantheon store on Oxford Street, M&S is also testing a more traditional way of selling footwear. The traditional shelves of shoes from which customers help themselves have been largely replaced by stylish displays and with staff on hand to produce the right size from a stockroom.

Analysts welcomed the changes but questioned the speed with which shoppers around the country would see a difference in their local stores. They also queried Bolland's reassurance that the new look would not add to costs.

"We think it will take a number of seasons before there is a marked improvement in both like-for-like sales and profits of womenswear and costs are likely to be more significant than expected at the start of the process a year ago," said Freddie George, an analyst at Cantor.

webTitle: Glencore Xstrata reveals $2bn merger savings

fields.standfirst: Figure achieved through layoffs, office closures and marketing and financial benefits is four times the initial estimate
fields.body:
Glencore Xstrata, the commodity trading and mining company run by the billionaire Ivan Glasenberg, has promised shareholders it will make at least $2bn (£1.3bn) of savings from the $44bn takeover of Xstrata.

Glasenberg, who owns 8.3% of the company's shares, worth £3.5bn, said closing 33 Xstrata offices and firing more than 1,800 employees had saved $1.4bn. The total savings, which include marketing and financial benefits, are four times the $500m it had initially estimated from the biggest ever takeover in the mining industry.

In his first detailed presentation since sealing the takeover in May, Glasenberg promised investors more savings in the future "as we delve deeper into the assets … I am sure there is more to go".

Glasenberg has been under pressure to demonstrate benefits of the takeover after a drop in commodity prices forced the company to write down the value of Xstrata assets by $7.7bn last month.

Glencore's shares rose 2.3% to 329p on Tuesday, the highest since May.

Glasenberg collected a $173m dividend from his stake in the company last year. Other senior executives own a further 16% of the company.

webTitle: Luxury £5.25m apartment in One Hyde Park repossessed

fields.standfirst: Receiver places one-bedroom flat in London's most expensive residential development back on market
fields.body:
A one-bedroom apartment in London's most expensive apartment complex, One Hyde Park, has been repossessed and is back on the market for £5.25m – "an exciting opportunity", according to estate agent Strutt & Parker, which has been appointed by the receiver.

The 988 sq ft apartment – a 17ft x 10ft bedroom, a bathroom and a 24ft x 13ft reception room, with a little kitchen behind a sliding door – is an "entry level" home, according the estate agent. Its local shop is Harrods and the apartment has its own temperature-controlled wine storage system.

In a glossy brochure, Strutt & Parker boasts of the development's "unrivalled facilities" including a swimming pool, gym, squash court, spa, cinema and virtual golf simulator.

Strutt & Parker told London's prime property agents: "We are now appointed by the receivers to find a buyer quickly for the property and hope that one of your buyers may benefit from being able to move quickly?"

Built by Christian Candy's CPC Group and Waterknights, a property developer owned by Qatar's prime minister, apartments at One Hyde Park were sold for almost double the price of other properties in the area – up to £7,500 per square foot.

But analysts said the development had proved a bad deal compared with other prime properties in the capital, where prices have been shooting up. Tracy Kellett of BDI Home Finders claimed that One Hyde Park "was the worst property investment in London".

The steel and glass towers overlooking Hyde Park have never been far away from controversy. Almost 80% of the 72 super-luxury apartments have been bought by anonymous offshore entities – the majority of them registered in the British Virgin Islands, enabling them to avoid UK capital gains tax and inheritance tax. Only a handful of the residents are registered to pay council tax.

In a legal case last year, the alleged true owner of a flat sold for £3.6m – the bankrupt Irish property developer Ray Grehan who was being pursued by Ireland's Nama bad bank – was identified and accused of an attempt to cheat his creditors.

Grehan sold the flat to a company where he was a beneficiary and the sale price was said to be less than the true value of the flat. Nama believed the transaction was fraudulent but Grehan denied any wrongdoing.

In July the Irish Times reported that Grehan had agreed to sell his apartment at One Hyde Park, with 85% of the proceeds to go to Nama. Grehan's flat was estimated to be worth about £5m.

It was Christian Candy's CPC Group which built One Hyde Park with Waterknights. Candy & Candy were the interior designers and project managers for the development.

webTitle: Financial Stability Board sees dangers in Bank of England 'group-think'

fields.standfirst: Central bank supervisory body, chaired by Bank of England governor, warns of crossover in membership between the Bank's financial policy committee and monetary policy committee
fields.body:
The Bank of England must guard against "group-think" as it shoulders formidable new powers over Britain's financial sector, according to a report published by global watchdog the Financial Stability Board.

In its latest healthcheck of the UK, the FSB – which is chaired by the Bank's governor, Mark Carney – praises the overall thrust of the reforms introduced by the coalition to prevent a future financial crisis, which included bringing the job of supervising the financial sector back to Threadneedle Street. But it warns that the crossover in membership between the Bank's financial policy committee, tasked with spotting future bubbles, and the interest rate-setting monetary policy committee, risks creating "group-think".

"Centralising the supervisory and systemic roles within the BoE may improve information flow, co-ordination, and a shared sense of purpose. On the other hand, such an arrangement increases the potential of creating a 'group-think' mentality, particularly since a large scope of responsibility is vested in a small number of senior executives," it warns.

Carney, and his deputies Paul Tucker and Charlie Bean, all sit on both of these key committees; though they are joined by independent members, which the FSB acknowledges will help to mitigate the risks.

The FSB is also concerned about how the fledgling FPC will exercise its authority to make recommendations to the new banking regulator, the Prudential Regulation Authority – also an arm of the Bank.

In his first setpiece speech last month, Carney promised to keep a close eye on the risks of a new housing bubble emerging, and use "tools other than interest rates", to clamp down on lending.

If its members spot a bubble emerging, one new tool at the FPC's disposal is to issue a so-called "comply or explain" directive to the regulator, asking it to control the availability of credit across the economy, for example.

But the FSB warns that it is unclear, "whether this steer should be expressed in general terms by leaving the details of the response to the agencies, or whether the recommendations can set out specific regulatory details that should be changed".

If the FPC's instructions to bank regulators end up being too detailed, the FSB says, "the FPC may end up having substantial influence over the details of the prudential framework - an outcome that may create tensions between the relevant agencies and confusion in the marketplace." It calls on the Bank to "publicly clarify the FPC's approach". Helping the public to understand how the FPC works may also be a challenge, the FSB warns, especially since it has more levers to pull than the MPC.

"The FPC will need to better develop understanding and acceptability of the new framework and policy among market participants and the public. This is a more challenging task than for monetary policy decisions given the broad remit of possible policies that can be employed (or recommended) by the FPC and their more complex transmission mechanism." It suggests the Bank might want to use, "targeted public speeches, meetings with industry representatives and the public, website development)," to get its message across.

The Basel-based FSB was established in the wake of the Great Crash to co-ordinate the work of central banks and regulators around the world in strengthening the international financial system.

Its "peer review" of the UK was carried out by an international team of senior central bankers, headed by Luiz Pereira da Silva, deputy governor of the central bank of Brazil.

Carney said: "The Bank of England welcomes the final report of the FSB's Peer Review of the UK's financial sector standard and policies, and looks forward to working with other relevant UK authorities to review and assess the Report's recommendations."
fields.bodyText: The Bank of England must guard against "group-think" as it shoulders formidable new powers over Britain's financial sector, according to a report published by global watchdog the Financial Stability Board. In its latest healthcheck of the UK, the FSB – which is chaired by the Bank's governor, Mark Carney – praises the overall thrust of the reforms introduced by the coalition to prevent a future financial crisis, which included bringing the job of supervising the financial sector back to Threadneedle Street. But it warns that the crossover in membership between the Bank's financial policy committee, tasked with spotting future bubbles, and the interest rate-setting monetary policy committee, risks creating "group-think". "Centralising the supervisory and systemic roles within the BoE may improve information flow, co-ordination, and a shared sense of purpose. On the other hand, such an arrangement increases the potential of creating a 'group-think' mentality, particularly since a large scope of responsibility is vested in a small number of senior executives," it warns. Carney, and his deputies Paul Tucker and Charlie Bean, all sit on both of these key committees; though they are joined by independent members, which the FSB acknowledges will help to mitigate the risks. The FSB is also concerned about how the fledgling FPC will exercise its authority to make recommendations to the new banking regulator, the Prudential Regulation Authority – also an arm of the Bank. In his first setpiece speech last month, Carney promised to keep a close eye on the risks of a new housing bubble emerging, and use "tools other than interest rates", to clamp down on lending. If its members spot a bubble emerging, one new tool at the FPC's disposal is to issue a so-called "comply or explain" directive to the regulator, asking it to control the availability of credit across the economy, for example. But the FSB warns that it is unclear, "whether this steer should be expressed in general terms by leaving the details of the response to the agencies, or whether the recommendations can set out specific regulatory details that should be changed". If the FPC's instructions to bank regulators end up being too detailed, the FSB says, "the FPC may end up having substantial influence over the details of the prudential framework - an outcome that may create tensions between the relevant agencies and confusion in the marketplace." It calls on the Bank to "publicly clarify the FPC's approach". Helping the public to understand how the FPC works may also be a challenge, the FSB warns, especially since it has more levers to pull than the MPC. "The FPC will need to better develop understanding and acceptability of the new framework and policy among market participants and the public. This is a more challenging task than for monetary policy decisions given the broad remit of possible policies that can be employed (or recommended) by the FPC and their more complex transmission mechanism." It suggests the Bank might want to use, "targeted public speeches, meetings with industry representatives and the public, website development)," to get its message across. The Basel-based FSB was established in the wake of the Great Crash to co-ordinate the work of central banks and regulators around the world in strengthening the international financial system. Its "peer review" of the UK was carried out by an international team of senior central bankers, headed by Luiz Pereira da Silva, deputy governor of the central bank of Brazil. Carney said: "The Bank of England welcomes the final report of the FSB's Peer Review of the UK's financial sector standard and policies, and looks forward to working with other relevant UK authorities to review and assess the Report's recommendations."

webTitle: Is Wonga for Business trying to rebrand?

fields.standfirst: UK's best-known payday lender recently applied to have the trading name Everline added to its credit licence and has now registered the domain name Everline.com
fields.body:
What might Wonga be up to? The UK's best-known payday lender, which last week reported profits of £62.5m in 2012, recently applied to have the trading name Everline added to its credit licence and on Tuesday the domain name Everline.com was registered by its parent company WDFC SA. Credit licences, which are issued by the Office of Fair Trading, cover UK lending only, so the addition isnot related to Wonga's recent purchase of a stake in the Indian lender Nahar Credits.

The lender's annual report stated an "intention to develop our suite of products" and Wonga's co-founder Errol Damelin has previously said he might launch a savings account or mortgage. (If he offered a savings product with an interest rate anywhere near the 1% a day that it charges borrowers, that would be a winner, whatever it was called.) .

Or could Everline be a new name for an existing service? Wonga for Business doesn't seem to have made the impact the lender might have hoped for. The annual report said it was "too early to share all our numbers", but quoted lending of some £500,000 a month to firms. In contrast, when another relative newcomer to the sector, Shawbrook bank, published figures on Monday, it said it had lent £766m to small firms in the last two years. The appetite seems to be there, but maybe the Wonga name is offputting to business customers. Wonga is unwilling to comment, so currently there's no official line on Everline.

The centre-left Democratic Party (PD), which has the largest number of members on the 23-member committee, has said it will vote down three motions that would delay the hearings but the committee may delay a vote to win more time, according to two sources close to the committee. "There won't be a vote tonight," one parliamentarian, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told Reuters. "The chairman of the panel is working to head off a vote." One protest was held by teachers and university university staff against government cutbacks and layoffs, while employees from a mining company held a separate demo against plans to privatise their firm. Over in Paris, a protester climbed a statue in the Republic Square to hold up a placard calling for a levy on the profits of firms in the CAC 40, to fund the country's pension schemes: Confirmation via M&G's Bond Vigilantes that Spain's borrowing costs are now below Italy's, due to the political drama being played out in Rome (see 4.39pm) I mentioned this morning that French industrial production had shrunk again in July, by 0.6% month-on-month, dashing hopes of a rise (see 8.21am for details and graphs). Economist Shaun Richards has taken a deeper look at the numbers, and warns that French industry is withering: He writes here: If we look at the underlying indices we see that French industrial production is at 97.8 and manufacturing is at 98 if we take the working-day and seasonally adjusted numbers. We can learn a lot by simply looking backwards as they were 100.2 and 100.1 respectively in April which again challenges the growth agenda somewhat. But I wish to go deeper and give you the numbers from the beginning of this series and when you see them you will get my point. In January 1990 they were 104.1 and 111.7 respectively. They are extraordinary declines are they not? I would like to emphasise the manufacturing numbers as I have just scanned the 1990s and there is no reading as low as that of July 2013 that I can see. It peaked at 122.1 in December 2000 which means that it has fallen by just under 20% since then. Is that trend the future for manufacturing in France? Shaun is also good value (as ever) on today's protests: Today opens with news of a strike against pension reform in France. However this “reform” only currently applies to the private-sector as we note that the larger potential deficit in public-sector pensions is being ignored. How very Euro area! It remains to be seen if the strike spreads to the public-sector. Also as some of the reforms are well beyond the term of President Hollande’s office (2020-35) we see not only some can-kicking here but also another entry in a possible “generational war”. After all he promised retirement at 62 not so long ago but the young will find that much harder after these reforms. Perhaps another form of strike will also be on French minds today as the national football team has not scored for five matches and it time for another round of World Cup qualifiers. I"m almost certain this isn't part of the cycling proficiency test.... Over in Italy, a cross-party parliamentary committee will meet tonight at 8pm local time (7pm BST) to resume talks on whether Silvio Berlusconi should be barred from the Senate. The discussions, following Berlusconi's final appeal defeat over a tax fraud conviction, began yesterday. Berlusconi's allies have been piling on the pressure today, warning that the former leader's PDL party could withdraw from the coalition government if the hearing goes against Berlusconi. PDL secretary Angelino Alfano took to Facebook today to criticise the "amazing" and "unbearable" actions of the centre-left PD party, for pushing on with this week's hearings. PD, of course, are the PDL's coalition partners. Alfano also claimed: They prefer to bring the country to its knees just to eliminate their historic political enemy via judicial means. The PDL want the decision on Berlusconi's fate delayed while an appeal to the European Court of Human Rights is heard. Renato Brunetta, floor leader of the PDL in the lower house, warned that Enrico Letta's government could crash down if PD, and the radical Five-Star Movement, press on with expulsion. Brunetta told RAI state radio: If the Democratic Party and Grillo's people decide this evening to vote against the proposals, the Democratic Party will bring down the Letta government. A full Senate vote would still need to take place before Berlusconi could be expelled. But the situation is causing some concern in the financial markets -- as flagged up earlier, Italian government debt is no longer seen as safer than Spanish. Italian 10-year bonds are trading at yields of 4.531% today, compared to Spain's 4.518%. Car workers, from Peugeot Citroen's doomed Paris plant at Aulnay-sous-Bois took part in the the protest march in the French capital today. One carried a banner calling for a return to the "37.5 years" -- the old minimum career before qualifying for a pension. Good luck with that ... Relations between Peugeot's workers and management have been quite fraught since it announced plans to shut the Aulnay-sous-Bois factory in 2014. The company's bosses are in Frankfurt this week for the French city's Auto Show, where chief executive Philippe Varin warned that further cutbacks will be needed to revive the group's fortunes. Varin told Reuters that discussions were underway about cutting production further: Speaking at the Frankfurt auto show, Varin confirmed that production line shutdowns were "exactly the discussion we are having" but said he would present cutbacks to unions before announcing details. Asked whether more than one line would have to go, Varin replied: "That is part of the negotiation ... It also depends on our assumptions for the market and our market share - discussions are ongoing." Decent turnout in Paris for today's protests too: Today's demonstrations in France are hardly a repeat of 1968 and all that. Associated Press reports that they're not even up the 2010 vintage, when anger over President Sarkozy's pension reforms sparked days of protests and petrol shortages. Here's AP's take: A nationwide strike against the French government's plan to plug a 20-billion-euro hole in the country'spension system has elicited the equivalent of a Gallic shrug. The strike called by four unions on Tuesday against the Socialist government's proposed reform had almost no impact on traffic across France's rail, bus and subway systems or other public services. That's a sharp contrast to the sometimes violent protests that erupted the last time a French government attempted to reform its retirement system. Demonstrations in Paris and 180 other towns and cities were taking place, but with some moderate unions declining to participate, mobilization withered. The French plan would gradually extend the number of years employees must pay contributions to claim a full pension, from 41.5 years now to 43 years in 2035. Over in Nicosia, the Bank of Cyprus is holding an AGM -- and facing the wrath of customers who lost large sums of money through the country's bailout deal. Economics history professor Alex Apostolides is there, tweeting the key events. It's shake-up time on Wall Street. Tech firm Hewlett-Packard, Bank of America and aluminium producer Alcoa are all being given the order of the boot from the Dow Jones industrial average. They'll be replaced by Goldman Sachs, Nike and Visa. Apparently it will make the Dow more representative (it only holds 30 companies). The index has only been revised some 53 times since it was created in 1907... ...however, there's already a backlash, with claims that the move will give Goldman too much influence on the Dow. That's because the Dow is a price-weighted index, so a one dollar move in any constituent's share price has the same impact (regardless of whether the company's share price is $1 or $100). Goldman's share price is around $159, compared to Bank of America's $14, so Goldman will have much more influence on the way the Dow moves (there's a more detailed explanation on Business Insider). It's official, the Bank of England is considering bringing in plastic bank notes (as flagged at 11.57am) And they'll be 30% smaller: A couple more snaps from Lyon as the nationwide day of protest action against France's pension reforms picks up pace: One group of protesters in Lyon lugged a makeshift coffin along with them. Just in, new photos from Marseille showing that the march against the French government's pension reforms is underway. Thousands of people took part in the march, according to the Corbis photo agency, with some people carrying flares (thus the smoke). This is just one of the 180 or so protests scheduled for today. However, as flagged up earlier, France's transport system is holding up well -- suggesting that this won't be a repeat of the violence of 2010 when Nicolas Sarkozy's government tried to reform the pension system. Europe's plans to impose a financial transaction tax appear to be on the ropes. Reuters has got its hands on a legal opinion from Brussels' own lawyers, which concludes that the FTT is illegal. Although it's not a binding recommendation, it could well signal that the idea of levying a flat fee on stocks, bonds, derivatives, repurchase agreements and securities lending is doomed. Eleven countries have said they would impose an FTT. Supporters say it would combat short-term speculation in the markets, and make the banks pay back some of the cost of the financial crisis. However, critics have warned it would drive financial trade out of Europe -- with the UK bringing legal action against the FTT (even though Britain isn't joining). Here's the story: Exclusive: EU lawyers say transaction tax plan is illegal I mentioned in yesterday afternoon's liveblog that Greece, Italy, Spain and Portugal had all tumbled down an annual ranking of happiness published by the UN. Judge Christopher Clarke told a "packed courtroom" (apparently) at the London Courts of Justice that GKP , and it alone, owns the Shaikan Field. Gulf Keystone Petroleum wins long standing court case In France, people are gathering at 180 cities to protests against Francois Hollande's pension reforms, although (as expected) the turnout is limited (so far). Marches are due to begin at 2pm local time, or 1pm BST, with Mailly planning to lead a rally in Paris. The head of the CGT union, Thierry Lepaon, has suggested that turnout this afternoon will be "surprising". Instead, today's march is being billed as a show of force. Lepaon explained: People are very worried It's important for workers to know they need to show their strength on social issues. Reuters reports that there's been limited disruption to transport links so far. Heads-up: The Bank of England is considering introducing plastic bank notes in the UK, and will release details of its plans this afternoon. Such shinier, non-tear notes are already used in a number of countries, including Canada, the home country of the new Bank of England governor, Mark Carney. More here: UK mulls switch to plastic bank notes This won't be news to Radio 5 Live listeners, of course: Speaking of Greece... the government has announced this morning that it has achieved a primary surplus so far this year. The Greek finance ministry said that the central government had a primary budget surplus of €2.92bn between January and August, the finance ministry said. Moscovici added that more than two-thirds of the adjustments in the 2014 budget will come from savings on government spending rather than tax rises. Worth remembering that a 3.7% deficit was already some way over the EC's target of 3%, with Paris having been granted two more years to get its borrowing into line. We also have disappointing economic data from France this morning. Industrial production shrank by 0.6% in July, dashing analyst hopes for a 0.6% rise. Manufacturing output fell by 0.7% during the month, INSEE reported, and is 1.1% smaller compared to a year ago. July's drop was driven by a 4.2% decline in "the manufacture of coke and refined petroleum products", followed by energy, mining, and food production. France officially exited recession in the April-June quarter. This data suggests the summer could be a struggle. There are already signs that today's strike is hitting French transport links. According to this status update page, there are delays of up to one hour on the line to Paris's Orly Airport. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the global economy, the financial markets, the eurozone crisis and the business world. After a quiet summer, anti-austerity protests will return to the streets of the eurozone today as French unions hold a day of protest action against Francois Hollande's pension reforms. "There won't be a vote tonight," one parliamentarian, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told Reuters. "The chairman of the panel is working to head off a vote." 

5.19pm BST

Two different demonstrations took place in Athens tonight. One protest was held by teachers and university university staff against government cutbacks and layoffs, while employees from a mining company held a separate demo against plans to privatise their firm.

5.15pm BST

Over in Paris, a protester climbed a statue in the Republic Square to hold up a placard calling for a levy on the profits of firms in the CAC 40, to fund the country's pension schemes:

5.11pm BST

Confirmation via M&G's Bond Vigilantes that Spain's borrowing costs are now below Italy's, due to the political drama being played out in Rome (see 4.39pm)

Updated at 5.12pm BST

4.59pm BST

I mentioned this morning that French industrial production had shrunk again in July, by 0.6% month-on-month, dashing hopes of a rise (see 8.21am for details and graphs).

Economist Shaun Richards has taken a deeper look at the numbers, and warns that French industry is withering:

He writes here:

If we look at the underlying indices we see that French industrial production is at 97.8 and manufacturing is at 98 if we take the working-day and seasonally adjusted numbers. We can learn a lot by simply looking backwards as they were 100.2 and 100.1 respectively in April which again challenges the growth agenda somewhat. But I wish to go deeper and give you the numbers from the beginning of this series and when you see them you will get my point. In January 1990 they were 104.1 and 111.7 respectively.

They are extraordinary declines are they not? I would like to emphasise the manufacturing numbers as I have just scanned the 1990s and there is no reading as low as that of July 2013 that I can see. It peaked at 122.1 in December 2000 which means that it has fallen by just under 20% since then. Is that trend the future for manufacturing in France?

Shaun is also good value (as ever) on today's protests:

Today opens with news of a strike against pension reform in France. However this “reform” only currently applies to the private-sector as we note that the larger potential deficit in public-sector pensions is being ignored. How very Euro area! It remains to be seen if the strike spreads to the public-sector. Also as some of the reforms are well beyond the term of President Hollande’s office (2020-35) we see not only some can-kicking here but also another entry in a possible “generational war”.

After all he promised retirement at 62 not so long ago but the young will find that much harder after these reforms.

Perhaps another form of strike will also be on French minds today as the national football team has not scored for five matches and it time for another round of World Cup qualifiers.

Updated at 5.03pm BST

4.53pm BST

I"m almost certain this isn't part of the cycling proficiency test....

4.39pm BST

Talks to resume tonight over Berlusconi

Over in Italy, a cross-party parliamentary committee will meet tonight at 8pm local time (7pm BST) to resume talks on whether Silvio Berlusconi should be barred from the Senate.

The discussions, following Berlusconi's final appeal defeat over a tax fraud conviction, began yesterday. Berlusconi's allies have been piling on the pressure today, warning that the former leader's PDL party could withdraw from the coalition government if the hearing goes against Berlusconi.

PDL secretary Angelino Alfano took to Facebook today to criticise the "amazing" and "unbearable" actions of the centre-left PD party, for pushing on with this week's hearings. PD, of course, are the PDL's coalition partners.

 Alfano also claimed:

They prefer to bring the country to its knees just to eliminate their historic political enemy via judicial means.

The PDL want the decision on Berlusconi's fate delayed while an appeal to the European Court of Human Rights is heard.

Renato Brunetta, floor leader of the PDL in the lower house, warned that Enrico Letta's government could crash down if PD, and the radical Five-Star Movement, press on with expulsion.

Brunetta told RAI state radio:

If the Democratic Party and Grillo's people decide this evening to vote against the proposals, the Democratic Party will bring down the Letta government.

A full Senate vote would still need to take place before Berlusconi could be expelled. But the situation is causing some concern in the financial markets -- as flagged up earlier, Italian government debt is no longer seen as safer than Spanish. Italian 10-year bonds are trading at yields of 4.531% today, compared to Spain's 4.518%.

Updated at 4.40pm BST

3.56pm BST

Car workers, from Peugeot Citroen's doomed Paris plant at Aulnay-sous-Bois took part in the the protest march in the French capital today. 

One carried a banner calling for a return to the "37.5 years" -- the old minimum career before qualifying for a pension. Good luck with that ...

Relations between Peugeot's workers and management have been quite fraught since it announced plans to shut the Aulnay-sous-Bois factory in 2014.

The company's bosses are in Frankfurt this week for the French city's Auto Show, where chief executive Philippe Varin warned that further cutbacks will be needed to revive the group's fortunes.

Varin told Reuters that discussions were underway about cutting production further:

Speaking at the Frankfurt auto show, Varin confirmed that production line shutdowns were "exactly the discussion we are having" but said he would present cutbacks to unions before announcing details.

Asked whether more than one line would have to go, Varin replied: "That is part of the negotiation ... It also depends on our assumptions for the market and our market share - discussions are ongoing."

3.32pm BST

Decent turnout in Paris for today's protests too: 

3.06pm BST

Today's demonstrations in France are hardly a repeat of 1968 and all that.

Associated Press reports that they're not even up the 2010 vintage, when anger over President Sarkozy's pension reforms sparked days of protests and petrol shortages.

Here's AP's take:

A nationwide strike against the French government's plan to plug a 20-billion-euro hole in the country'spension system has elicited the equivalent of a Gallic shrug.

The strike called by four unions on Tuesday against the Socialist government's proposed reform had almost no impact on traffic across France's rail, bus and subway systems or other public services. That's a sharp contrast to the sometimes violent protests that erupted the last time a French government attempted to reform its retirement system.

Demonstrations in Paris and 180 other towns and cities were taking place, but with some moderate unions declining to participate, mobilization withered.

The French plan would gradually extend the number of years employees must pay contributions to claim a full pension, from 41.5 years now to 43 years in 2035.

3.02pm BST

Over in Nicosia, the Bank of Cyprus is holding an AGM -- and facing the wrath of customers who lost large sums of money through the country's bailout deal.

Economics history professor Alex Apostolides is there, tweeting the key events. 

2.38pm BST

Three in, three out on the Dow Jones

It's shake-up time on Wall Street. Tech firm Hewlett-Packard, Bank of America and aluminium producer Alcoa are all being given the order of the boot from the Dow Jones industrial average.

They'll be replaced by Goldman Sachs, Nike and Visa. Apparently it will make the Dow more representative (it only holds 30 companies).

The index has only been revised some 53 times since it was created in 1907...

...however, there's already a backlash, with claims that the move will give Goldman too much influence on the Dow.

That's because the Dow is a price-weighted index, so a one dollar move in any constituent's share price has the same impact (regardless of whether the company's share price is $1 or $100). Goldman's share price is around $159, compared to Bank of America's $14, so Goldman will have much more influence on the way the Dow moves (there's a more detailed explanation on Business Insider).

2.14pm BST

It's official, the Bank of England is considering bringing in plastic bank notes (as flagged at 11.57am) And they'll be 30% smaller:

A couple more snaps from Lyon as the nationwide day of protest action against France's pension reforms picks up pace:

One group of protesters in Lyon lugged a makeshift coffin along with them.

1.30pm BST

Photos: Protests in Marseille

Just in, new photos from Marseille showing that the march against the French government's pension reforms is underway.

Thousands of people took part in the march, according to the Corbis photo agency, with some people carrying flares (thus the smoke). This is just one of the 180 or so protests scheduled for today.

However, as flagged up earlier, France's transport system is holding up well -- suggesting that this won't be a repeat of the violence of 2010 when Nicolas Sarkozy's government tried to reform the pension system.

Updated at 1.39pm BST

1.20pm BST

Reuters: FTT is illegal, says EU lawyers

Europe's plans to impose a financial transaction tax appear to be on the ropes.

Reuters has got its hands on a legal opinion from Brussels' own lawyers, which concludes that the FTT is illegal. Although it's not a binding recommendation, it could well signal that the idea of levying a flat fee on stocks, bonds, derivatives, repurchase agreements and securities lending is doomed.

Eleven countries have said they would impose an FTT. Supporters say it would combat short-term speculation in the markets, and make the banks pay back some of the cost of the financial crisis.

However, critics have warned it would drive financial trade out of Europe -- with the UK bringing legal action against the FTT (even though Britain isn't joining).

I mentioned in yesterday afternoon's liveblog that Greece, Italy, Spain and Portugal had all tumbled down an annual ranking of happiness published by the UN.

Now, Business Insider have just launched a nifty map showing which are the happiest, and least happy, places to live:

In the City, shares in Gulf Keystone Petroleum have spiked 27% after the firm won a closely watched court case over the ownership of a big oil field in Kurdistan.

Judge Christopher Clarke told a "packed courtroom" (apparently) at the London Courts of Justice that GKP , and it alone, owns the Shaikan Field. Cue much action as investors try to pile into GKP -- which was already a popular share with small punters.

Our markets reporter Nick Fletcher has the full story:

A judge in London dismissed a claim by US-based Excalibur Ventures that it had the right to 30% of Gulf's assets in northern Iraq.

The case has been overshadowing Gulf for three years, but now it has been resolved analysts believe it could be attractive to larger rivals wanting to increase their presence in the region.

Gulf Keystone Petroleum wins long standing court case

Updated at 12.29pm BST

12.13pm BST

French workers prepare to march

In France, people are gathering at 180 cities to protests against Francois Hollande's pension reforms, although (as expected) the turnout is limited (so far).

Hardline FO union leader Jean-Claude Mailly has told France 2 TV that he doesn't expect a "tidal wave" of opposition, despite worker anger over Hollande's proposal that they pay larger contributions and wait longer until they retire.

Marches are due to begin at 2pm local time, or 1pm BST, with Mailly planning to lead a rally in Paris.

The head of the CGT union, Thierry Lepaon, has suggested that turnout this afternoon will be "surprising".

However, it appears that neither Mailly nor Lepaon are demanding that Hollande drops his plans for pension reforms (as explained earlier, France will face a €20bn pensions black hole by 2020 unless changes are made).

Instead, today's march is being billed as a show of force. Lepaon explained:

People are very worried

It's important for workers to know they need to show their strength on social issues.

Reuters reports that there's been limited disruption to transport links so far.

11.57am BST

Heads-up: The Bank of England is considering introducing plastic bank notes in the UK, and will release details of its plans this afternoon.

My colleague Katie Allen reports:

Notes made of polymer, a plastic-like material, are thought to be more durable than notes printed on cotton paper, as they are currently in Britain.

Such shinier, non-tear notes are already used in a number of countries, including Canada, the home country of the new Bank of England governor, Mark Carney.

More here: UK mulls switch to plastic bank notes

This won't be news to Radio 5 Live listeners, of course:

11.52am BST

Speaking of Greece... the government has announced this morning that it has achieved a primary surplus so far this year.

This means the Athens government had money left over after paying its bills, if you exclude the cost of servicing its debt pile.

The Greek finance ministry said that the central government had a primary budget surplus of €2.92bn between January and August, the finance ministry said.

 Dragging Greece's finances back to a primary surplus is a key goal of the Greek bailout plan -- it should make it easier to haggle additional help from its lenders next year (if needed).

However, a caveat is needed -- as Reuters explains:

It is not directly comparable with its bailout targets as it excludes the budgets of local government and social security funds and includes one-off revenue from euro zone central banks.

It is also on a cash basis, whereas the budget figures against which Greece's performance will be judged are based on an accrual basis, which classifies revenues and expenses differently.

Still, deputy finance minister Christos Staikouras is upbeat, declaring that;

The target to reach a surplus at the end of the year becomes more and more feasible.

11.34am BST

There are also likely to be anti-austerity protests in Greece this month, after school teachers voted last night to hold rolling strikes against the Athens government's 'mobility scheme' (through which thousands of jobs could be cut).

As Greece's Kathimerini explains:

High school teachers have opted to launch rolling five-day strikes from September 16 to protest the government’s decision to place hundreds of educators in a civil service mobility scheme.

11.17am BST

Market update

Optimism that the Syrian crisis is easing have driven shares up worldwide today, with the Dubai stock market closing 8.5% higher in the last few minutes. The Abi Dhabi exchange is up 5.5%.

This follows the news that France will bring a resolution to the UN Security Council to put Syria's chemical weapons stocks beyond use (see Matt Weaver's Middle East liveblog for details)

 Europe's stock markets have also been pushed higher by decent economic data from China early this morning (industrial production rose 10.4%, while retail sales gained 13.4%).

Germany's DAX was the biggest riser in Europe, while Italy's FTSE MIB was the weakest (reflecting political jitters - see 9.19am):

The oil price is also down, with a barrel of New York crude trading $1 lighter at $108.51. 

Mike van Dulken, head of research at Accendo Markets, comments:

An easing of geopolitical tensions regarding Syria, with Russia backing a proposal for surrender of weapons to avoid US intervention, has given sentiment a further boost, as has a second batch of positive overnight macro data from China.

Possibility of Fed tapering just round the corner, but markets look to have priced this in.... (I still say delayed on latest data, especially jobs, being mixed) and are more concerned with geopolitical stability.

Updated at 11.28am BST

10.29am BST

Dow Jones Newswires has more details of Christine Lagarde's comments about the "beautiful ship" that is the eurozone this morning (see 9.55am) in Paris: 

Greater fiscal integration would help the euro zone absorb shocks for individual countries, it would help with governance, and would limit contagion, Ms. Lagarde said.

The head of the IMF, a former French finance minister, identified several areas for work. She said Europe has made significant progress on increasing oversight of national budgets, but the rules will only be good if they are properly enforced. Ms. Lagarde also called for a stronger risk-sharing mechanism, such as a rainy day fund, and said there needs to be a credible pan-European backstop for the resolution of banks.

Progress has been made on a backstop for banks via its bailout fund--the European Stability Mechanism--but more clarity is needed, she added.

"It's really a question of making the ESM readily available in a clear articulated and simple way," she said. 

More here.

9.55am BST

Lagarde: the eurozone is a beautiful ship

Over in Paris, IMF chief Christine Lagarde has declared that the eurozone is a "beautiful ship" that needs a few urgent modifications to sail the troubled waters of the world economy.

Lagarde made the comments at a conference on creating fiscal union for the EU, as she called on European politicians to urgently conclude their work on banking union.

Lagarde said:

We very much think of the euro area as a beautiful ship that has been built, nurtured .. for the soft seas, but which is not yet completely finished for the rough ones.

A lot has been done in relation to banking union. If I have a message today it is that that particular part of the ship needs to be finished, needs to be completed and speed is of the essence.

(quotes via Reuters)

It's the latest analogy to explain the euro - back in July, Mario Draghi famously described the euro as a bumblebee (harking back to the myth that bumblebees shouldn't be able to fly).

Updated at 10.02am BST

9.39am BST

With 12 days to go until the crunch German elections, we've rounded up a handful of little-known facts about chancellor Angela Merkel

Six things you didn't know about Angela Merkel 

Courtesy of Stefan Kornelius, foreign editor of Süddeutsche Zeitung.

9.34am BST

Italian GDP revised down

Just in: The Italian recession is deeper than thought.

New data released this morning shows that the economy shrank by 0.3% in the second quarter of 2013, worse than the 0.2% first estimated. That means that Italian GDP is 2.1% less than a year ago, not the 2% as initially thought.

As if prime minister Enrico Letta didn't have enough to worry about with Silvio Berlusconi's fate still in the balance.

ISTAT, Italy's statistics body, reported that household spending continued to shrink in the face of Italy's economic woes, falling by 0.4% during the April-June quarter.

Capital spending and imports also dropped, by 0.3% quarter-on-quarter in both cases.

The year-on-year data underlined how Italy's economy has suffered over the last 12 months. Consumption is down by 2.4%, capital expenditure is 5.9% lower, while imports are down 4.6%. Exports are 0.2% higher than a year ago.

Here's the details:

Updated at 9.39am BST

9.19am BST

Italian borrowing costs exceed Spain's

Over in the bond markets, Italian government borrowing costs have risen above Spain's for the first time in 18 months.

It means Italy is being priced as a (slightly) bigger risk than Spain, in a sign that the Berlusconi Conundrum is dragging Italy towards a new crisis. 

Italian 10-year bond yields are trading at 4.485% this morning compared to 4.481% for Spain. That's must be a minor relief for Madrid, whose borrowing costs have been pushed up by allegations of government corruption and fears over bad bank debts.

And Berlusconi's future remains unclear. A Senate committee is due to reconvene tonight to continue discussing whether to kick him out of the Senate following his tax fraud conviction last month. Politicians continue to warn that Berlusconi could retaliate to any expulsion by withdrawing support for the coalition government.

9.04am BST

Elsewhere in the UK economy, house prices continue to romp ahead. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors reports that prices are rising at the fastest pace in seven years, fueling fears that the markets is getting out of control:

Soaring house prices spread across UK as surveyors warn of another bubble

8.56am BST

JLR gives UK a jobs boost

We have good news for the UK economy this morning (as jefferd points out in the comments):

Jaguar Land Rover will be hiring 1,700 new employees in the West Midlands, to support the production of a new range of sports cars based on cutting edge, lightweight aluminium technology.

Jaguar Land Rover creates 1,700 jobs and invests £1.5bn in aluminium cars

The luxury carmaker will invest £1.5bn to produce new models for both Jaguar and Land Rover, and the first new car to feature the technology will be a mid-sized sports sedan from Jaguar, launched in 2015. It will also be the first vehicle to feature an engine built at JLR's new £500m engine manufacturing facility near Wolverhampton.

The JLR chief executive, Ralf Speth, said the new investment and jobs were "further evidence" of the company's commitment to the UK car industry and its supply chain.

Speaking at the Frankfurt motor show on Tuesday, he said the new aluminium features signalled JLR's "ambitions to push the boundaries and redefine premium car ownership".

It marks an impressive revival for JLR, as Sky's Joel Hills explains:

Updated at 8.56am BST

8.44am BST

France's finance minister, Pierre Moscovici, has admitted this morning that France is unlikely to hit its target of a budget deficit of 3.7% of GDP for 2013.

 Speaking on French radio, Moscovici warned that:

The public deficit will be slightly higher than expected,

This echoes a warning from the country's auditor back in June. 

Moscovici added that more than two-thirds of the adjustments in the 2014 budget will come from savings on government spending rather than tax rises. 

Worth remembering that a 3.7% deficit was already some way over the EC's target of 3%, with Paris having been granted two more years to get its borrowing into line.

Updated at 8.44am BST

8.21am BST

We also have disappointing economic data from France this morning. Industrial production shrank by 0.6% in July, dashing analyst hopes for a 0.6% rise.

Manufacturing output fell by 0.7% during the month, INSEE reported, and is 1.1% smaller compared to a year ago.

July's drop was driven by a 4.2% decline in "the manufacture of coke and refined petroleum products", followed by energy, mining, and food production.

France officially exited recession in the April-June quarter. This data suggests the summer could be a struggle.

Here's the full breakdown:

Updated at 8.24am BST

8.12am BST

France's SNCF rail company is warning customers to expect a limited service today due to the strike action, with some trains cancelled on national, inter-city and TGV lines. 

There are already signs that today's strike is hitting French transport links. According to this status update page, there are delays of up to one hour on the line to Paris's Orly Airport. 

7.57am BST

French pension protests loom

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the global economy, the financial markets, the eurozone crisis and the business world.

After a quiet summer, anti-austerity protests will return to the streets of the eurozone today as French unions hold a day of protest action against Francois Hollande's pension reforms.

Let by the hardline CGT union, demonstrations will take place in 180 locations across France - as workers show their anger against Hollande's proposal to make them pay larger contributions and wait longer to collect their pensions.

Student unions and far-left groups are also expected to join the protests, in the latest expression of disquiet against Hollande's government.

The plans are meant to target France's pensions black hole, which is on track to hit €20bn by the end of the decade.

As Reuters explains:

The draft pension law, to be presented to cabinet on September 18th and sent to parliament shortly thereafter, aims to wipe out an annual deficit that will otherwise hit €20bn in 2020. Its main effect is to extend the pay-in period for pension contributions to 43 years by 2035 from 41.5 now.

Prime Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault's government submitted a new reform draft to France's top administrative court on Friday adding an amendment that will reduce advantageous conditions for pensioners who have more than three children starting in 2020. 

Analysts have criticised the bill as being too timid, but the CGT argues that it places an unfair burden on workers.

Opinion poll data released last night found that 61% of the public back the protestors, with four in five saying they are concerned about their pensions. 

However, the word from France is that today's protests are likely to be subdued, with some moderate unions declining to take part. It's unlikely to be a repeat of the pension protests that gripped the country for days in 2010.

Still, it should give an insight into the public mood in France, which faces many more tough decisions to bring its deficit into line in the years ahead.

I'll try to track the protests through the day, along with other key events as usual.

webTitle: Glencore Xstrata cost savings: Glasenberg trumps Bond

fields.standfirst: Ivan Glasenberg's $2bn targets imply that finding the $300m proposed by Sir John Bond would have been a breeze
fields.body:
Last year's downfall of Sir John Bond at Xstrata may feel like ancient corporate history but an eye-catching postscript arrived on Tuesday as Glencore's Ivan Glasenberg told his investors how much fat he can rip from the combined company's operations.

The relevance to Bond is that, in June last year, the Xstrata chairman attempted to make peace with his angry shareholders by linking proposed retention awards, worth £170m to 70 executives, to performance after merger with Glencore. Instead of cost savings of $50m (£31m), as advertised at the outset, the Xstrata high flyers would have to bend their backs and achieve $300m in order to hit the jackpot. This target, we were invited to believe, was terribly ambitious. Further, it was only likely to be hit if Xstrata's top brass could be incentivised to stay.

In the event, Bond convinced few people. His shareholders backed the deal with Glencore but shot down the retention scheme by an overwhelming majority, thereby forcing Bond's humiliating resignation.

So what does Glasenberg regard as the true level of potential cost-savings? Forget $50m. Forget $300m. He's shooting for $1.4bn. That is the main reason why total "synergies" from this merger-cum-takeover have increased from $500m to $2bn. Glasenberg even hinted on Tuesday that more might follow: "We are only just starting to comprehensively look at the combined mining and metallurgical operations."

Apologists for Bond might object this is a case of apples and pears, that his $300m can't be compared with Glasenberg's $2bn. They might argue that the deal changed when Glencore, under pressure from Xstrata's big Qatari shareholder, improved its terms but insisted there would be no place in the new boardroom for Xstrata chief executive Mick Davis. The first deal, it might be argued, was a merger; the revised version was a takeover, and they usually yield greater savings.

But that objection is surely a red herring. Whether you call it a merger or takeover, we're still talking about savings from the same set of Xstrata mines. The Glencore targets imply that finding $300m would have been a breeze and that the £170m of retention payments would have been money for old rope. Bond's scheme was outrageous, as we already knew. It now seems amazing that he ever thought it would fly.

webTitle: FTSE hits four week high as Syrian tensions ease, but GlaxoSmithKline falls on competition fears

fields.standfirst: Pharmaceutical group faces possible generic rivals to its Advair lung treatment after US draft guidance
fields.body:
Leading shares moved higher on more good economic data from China and hopes of a resolution to the Syrian dispute.

But GlaxoSmithKline missed out on the gains, falling 41.5p to 1598.5p on the prospective arrival of generic copies of its lung treatment Advair in the US, after draft guidance from regulators set out requirements for competitors.

Savvas Neophytou at Panmure Gordon said Glaxo's prospects were still dependent on Advair, which accounted for around 18% of revenues and 25% of profits. He said:

Following the investigation on selling practices in China and the failed trial on cancer candidate MAGE-A3 last week, the group's risk profile is increased with news overnight that the FDA had published draft guidance for the development of substitutable generic copies of combination inhaled drugs. This may result in increased competition to Glaxo's biggest selling product Advair. In recent years, the risk of a directly substitutable generic in the US had subsided, with a number of draft recommendations withdrawn. To boot, GSK's management has been more confident in dismissing the risk as relatively low probability.
Clearly generics will have to still undertake some sort of clinical trial (the length of which is yet to be determined) and that is onerous in the case of many generic manufacturers. Thus, in a worst case scenario, more competitors may enter the market but this is unlikely to become an 80%-90% discount generic market which is often the case when multiple generics are launched in pharmaceutical markets.

He kept his buy recommendation and £18.50 target:

Although not the cheapest, the company has been through the majority of its patent expiries, big liability settlements and boasts a strong balance sheet and very little M&A risk. With shareholder returns remaining strong, we remain buyers.

Reckitt Benckiser rose 81p to £44.45 despite a sell note from Liberum on worries about competition for its suboxone heroin substitute. Liberum said:

Orexo's Zubsolv tablets, competition for Reckitt's Suboxone film, will start retailing on September 16 with list prices as much as 25% below the price of Suboxone. We think consensus is wrong to assume no impact on Suboxone film earnings by 2014.

Overall the FTSE 100 finished 53.25 points higher at 6583.99, a near four week high, helped by Chinese industrial production hitting a 17 month high in August and signs of a possible compromise to defuse the prospect of an imminent US attack on Syria. The other major concern troubling the market - when the US Federal Reserve might end its bond buying programme - could become clearer after next week's Fed meeting.

webTitle: Banknotes: a short history

fields.standfirst: In 1694 the Bank of England was established to raise money for King William III's war against France. The Bank started to issue notes in return for deposits ...
fields.body:
Seventh century

First recorded use of paper money was in China in the seventh century. The practice did not become widespread in Europe for nearly a thousand years.

16th century

The goldsmith-bankers began to accept deposits, make loans and transfer funds. They also gave receipts for cash, that is to say gold coins, deposited with them. These receipts, known as "running cash notes", were made out in the name of the depositor and promised to pay him on demand. Many also carried the words "or bearer" after the name of the depositor, which allowed them to circulate in a limited way. The similar phrase "I promise to pay the bearer on demand the sum of ...." still appears on British banknotes today.

1694

In 1694 the Bank of England was established to raise money for King William III's war against France. The Bank started to issue notes in return for deposits. These notes were initially handwritten on Bank paper and signed by one of its cashiers. Today, all British banks carry the chief cashier's signature. After 1696, it was decided not to issue any notes worth less than £50 and since the average income then was less than £20 a year, most people went through life without ever coming into contact with banknotes.

18th century

The move towards fixed denomination notes started in the 18th century and from 1725 the Bank was issuing partly printed notes for completion by hand. The £ sign and the first digit were printed but other numerals and details were added by hand. By 1745 notes were being part printed in denominations ranging from £20 to £1,000.

In 1759, gold shortages caused by the seven years war forced the Bank to issue a £10 note for the first time. The first £5 notes followed in 1793 at the start of the war against Revolutionary France. In 1797 the uncertainty of the war caused a series of runs on the Bank and drained its bullion reserve. It was forced to stop paying out gold for its notes and instead it issued £1 and £2 notes. The Bank's nickname "the Old Lady of Threadneedle Street" has its roots in this so-called "restriction period" when gold reserves were short.

1853

Cashiers were finally relieved of the task of signing each note individually in 1853, when the first fully printed notes appeared.

Early 20th century

The first world war broke the link between notes and gold once again. The government needed to preservce bullion stocks and so the Bank stopped paying out gold for its notes. In 1914 the Treasury printed and issued 10 shilling and £1 notes. The gold standard was partially restored in 1925. Britain left the gold standard in 1931 and the note issue became entirely backed by securities instead of gold.

Late 20th century

Since 1970, the Bank's notes have honoured "great Britons", including scientist Isaac Newton, composer Edward Elgar and nurse Florence Nightingale. Final say on these historical figures went to the Bank governor.

The world's first polymer notes began to appear in the 1980s although there were some teething problems with ink sticking to the surface. Australia issued a polymer $10 commemorative banknote in 1988 to mark its bicentenary and went on to become the first country to use solely polymer notes.

21st century

Former governor Mervyn King's announcement that Sir Winston Churchill would be appearing on British banknotes, most likely in place of social reformer Elizabeth Fry, sparked anger at the disappearance of all female historical figures from notes. New governor Mark Carney responded with an announcement that Jane Austen would appear on future notes and he also launched a review of the selection process for such characters "to ensure that our notes represent the full diversity of British people".

Source: Bank of England and Reserve Bank of Australia

webTitle: Plastic banknotes Q&A: the lowdown on the switch to polymer

fields.standfirst: The what, why, when and how of the Bank of England's plan to switch from cotton paper to polymer banknotes
fields.body:
Why does the Bank of England want to switch from paper to plastic?

After carrying out a three-year study, the BoE says polymer notes are cleaner, more secure and last longer than existing notes which are printed on cotton paper. Crucially, they are also tougher to copy with elements, such as the transparent window, which make counterfeiting far more difficult.

What do they look and feel like?

Slippery and more bendy than existing notes, but just as easy to fold. The big difference is that the current watermark on notes, which features a faded-out image of the Queen, is likely to instead have a transparent image of Britannia. The Queen's head will remain, as will the current colours for the different denominations.

The notes will, however, be slightly smaller – by about 15% – bringing them in line with foreign notes and, the Bank says, making them easier to hold in wallets and purses.

Can I see one, please?

Shoppers in Oxford and Gateshead will be first in the queue. The BoE is launching a series of events in shopping centres across England and Wales, with the first as early as next week in the Westgate shopping centre in Oxford and the Metrocentre in Gateshead. But security conscious officials won't actually let them out of their hands entirely – you'll only be able to feel them while still in the hands of a Bank employee. Close-up images are not permitted in newspapers and, even for today's launch, the Bank would not allow any of the notes to be shown in TV studios without Bank security staff standing nearby.

With skyscrapers melting cars, will plastic money melt too?

In Canada there have been reports of notes left in car windows melting in the sun. Putting aside why anyone would leave a note visible on their dashboard, the Bank says that the polymer does not melt until the temperature hits 120C, surviving anything a British heatwave can throw at it. But don't try ironing them.

Will our new plastic money be 'Made in China'?

Absolutely not – this is one business where imports are banned. The notes will continue to be made at the Bank's secure facility in Debden, Essex, but De La Rue, the printer currently contracted to produce notes, may lose out to competitor Innovia, which makes most polymer notes including those used in Australia.

Why has it taken so long to bring them to England?

Mass circulation polymer notes were pioneered in Australia in 1992, although they are not an Aussie invention. The Isle of Man issued a £1 plastic banknote which circulated from 1983 to 1988, although Costa Rica lays claim to the first polymer note, made by Du Pont in 1982.

The BoE says it is able to use the experience of Australia and other major countries that have used polymer for years to help develop the most up-to-date and counterfeit-proof notes in the world.

Are they impossible to copy?

Even the BoE recognises that counterfeiting is impossible to avoid, but it believes polymer creates many more challenges for the crooks.

What will happen to self check-out machines?

The Bank says it is "engaging" with retailers on the introduction of polymer notes. It accepts there may be some changeover costs, but that over the longer term the benefits outweigh the costs. More polymer notes can be stacked in ATMs than paper notes, and they don't jam vending machines in the same way.

Will Scotland be getting them too?

No one knows yet. There are seven insitutions in Scotland and Northern Ireland able to issue notes apart from the Bank of England. They are also free to issue notes in other denominations, such as £1 or £100 notes, and will be able to take their own decisions on whether to switch to polymer.

I hate the idea of plastic money. Can we stop this?

The Bank promises an open and transparent consultation process lasting until 15 November. If public opposition to the new notes is intense it says it is prepared to back down. A final decision will be taken by the governor, Mark Carney, in December 2015.
